sn45.139:4.2: “Mendicants, the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, is said to be the best of all sentient beings—be they footless, with two feet, four feet, or many feet; with form or formless; with perception or without perception or with neither perception nor non-perception.
sn45.139:4.3: In the same way, all wholesome qualities are rooted in diligence and meet at diligence,
sn45.139:4.4: and diligence is said to be the best of them.
sn45.139:4.5: A mendicant who is diligent can expect to
sn45.139:4.6: develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path.
sn45.139:4.7: And how does a mendicant who is diligent develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path?
sn45.139:4.8: It’s when a mendicant develops right view, right motivation, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness,
sn45.139:4.9: and right samādhi, which relies on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripens as letting go.
sn45.139:4.10: That’s how a mendicant who is diligent develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path.
